title: Timeline of human vaccines - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: Timeline of human vaccines This is a timeline of the development of prophylactic human [vaccines](/wiki/Vaccine). Early vaccines may be listed by the first year of development or testing, but later entries usually show the year the vaccine finished trials and became available on the market. Although vaccines exist for the diseases listed below, only [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox) has been eliminated worldwide. The other vaccine-preventable illnesses continue to cause millions of deaths each year. [[1]](#cite_note-1) Currently, [polio](/wiki/Polio) and [measles](/wiki/Measles) are the targets of active worldwide [eradication campaigns](/wiki/Eradication_of_infectious_diseases). 200000000= - 1796 - [Gaston Ramon](/wiki/Gaston_Ramon), C. P. 1980 - [Smallpox declared eradicated](/wiki/Eradication_of_infectious_diseases#Smallpox)worldwide due to vaccination efforts - 1981 - First [vaccine](/wiki/Hepatitis_B_vaccine)for [hepatitis B](/wiki/Hepatitis_B)(first vaccine to target a cause of [cancer](/wiki/Cancer)) - 1984 - First [vaccine](/wiki/Varicella_vaccine)for [chicken pox](/wiki/Chicken_pox) - 1985 - First [vaccine](/wiki/Hib_vaccine)for [Haemophilus influenzae - 1989 - First vaccine fever](/wiki/Q_fever) [[12]](#cite_note-12) - 1990 - First [vaccine](/wiki/Hantavirus_vaccine)for [Hantavirus hemorrhagic syndrome](/wiki/Hantavirus_hemorrhagic_fever_with_renal_syndrome_(HFRS)) - 1991 - First [vaccine](/wiki/Hepatitis_A_vaccine)for [hepatitis A](/wiki/Hepatitis_A) [[13]](#cite_note-13) -
